elements.content: Highly efficient extraction of radioactive uranium from aqueous solution remains a serious task in the nuclear energy field. To address this, we here create an effective uranium ion trap by using a novel and facile strategy that introduces bioinspired moiety phytic acid (PA) into highly robust PCN-222. The resultant metal–organic framework (MOF)-based uranium ion trap (PCN-222-PA) with a high density of accessible phosphate groups exhibits a remarkable U­(VI) uptake capacity (401.6 mg·g–1), surpassing most of the reported phosphorus-modified MOFs and various other MOF adsorbents. Kinetics study reveals that PCN-222-PA can reduce the uranium concentration from 10 mg L–1 to 21 μg L–1, below the acceptable limit defined by the US Environmental Protection Agency. In addition, PCN-222-PA also shows good selectivity and high stability as well as excellent recyclability toward uranium capture. Our work demonstrates a new strategy to design functional MOFs with abundant phosphate groups and provides a new perspective for extracting uranium from aqueous solution.

Introduction

In consideration of environment and resource constraints, nuclear energy has been regarded as a cost-effective technology and is undergoing rapid development. Uranium [U(VI)], the heaviest naturally occurring element, is used as a raw material in the nuclear industry. Given the much higher uranium reserves in the ocean compared with those the land contains and the hazardous effect of radionuclides in nuclear wastewater on the environment or human health, novel materials are critically needed to extract uranium from an aqueous medium.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous materials composed of metal clusters/metal ions and organic ligands, have received considerable attention during the past 2 decades. Owing to their high surface areas, tailorable porosity, and tunable functionality, MOFs have shown excellent performance in many areas such as adsorption/separation, catalysis, sensing, and so on. Additionally, several types of functional groups/molecules could be introduced into MOF structures to selectively capture targeted guest species, offering opportunity to develop solid-phase adsorbents for metal ion (such as Hg, Pd, and Au) extraction from aqueous solution. Considering that phosphorus-containing groups always have strong affinity toward U­(VI), it is a wise way to decorate the pore walls of MOFs with such functional groups. However, the existing phosphorus-modified MOFs suffer from inferior U­(VI) uptake capacity and low removal efficiency, which have largely limited their effectiveness for U­(VI) capture. This can be ascribed to the following two reasons: one is the low density of phosphorus-containing groups in MOFs since such chelating groups are relatively difficult to be anchored into MOF structures in comparison with those such as −NH2, −COOH, and −OH. On the other hand, researchers always introduce phosphorus-based functional molecules with one or two binding sites into MOF structures for U­(VI) capture. In contrast, the introduction of multiple phosphorus-containing binding sites into MOFs toward U­(VI) has rarely been reported; the second is the poor dispersion of functional groups, thus rendering insufficient accessible binding sites in MOF materials. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop an effective MOF-based uranium ion trap that features well-distributed high-density phosphorus-containing binding sites.

Experimental Section

Preparation of the MOFs

PCN-222 was prepared according to the previous literature. PCN-222-PA was synthesized by adding 0.5 g of PCN-222 to 2.5 mM PA solution [v(dimethylformamide (DMF))/v(water) = 1:2]. The mixture was shaken for 24 h at room temperature and then centrifuged. Subsequently, the obtained solid was respectively washed with DMF, deionized water, and acetone several times and then dried overnight under vacuum conditions.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization

The MOF-based uranium ion trap was achieved by functionalizing PCN-222 with biochemical PA molecules (), which are considered to have strong affinity toward metal ions. PCN-222, a kind of Zr-MOFs with planar tetratopic carboxylic ligands of tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (H2TCPP), possesses a very large one-dimensional open channel with a diameter of up to 3.7 nm. In PCN-222, the vertex of the Zr nodes was coordinated with carboxyl groups, while the remaining other sites of Zr6 clusters are occupied by terminal groups. This Zr-MOF was selected as a host material owing to the following reasons: (i) a large pore surface area and mesoporous structure, thereby affording high-density well-dispersed PA molecules in MOFs; (ii) outstanding water/chemical stability, thus facilitating adsorbent regeneration; and (iii) the terminal groups on Zr6 clusters in PCN-222 are prone to be substituted by other ligands with phosphate groups through a solvent-assisted ligand incorporation method, making it easy to graft bioinspired PA molecules onto the host MOF material. The PA-modified PCN-222 was prepared by immersing the MOF solid in the PA solution at room temperature, which was considered as a convenient synthetic process.

elements.content: The successful grafting of PA molecules onto PCN-222 was also examined by FTIR, XPS, and ICP analyses. As shown in e, the FTIR spectra of PCN-222-PA reveal two new peaks at 574 and 1106 cm–1 compared with those of the original one, which can be attributed to the in-side-plane vibration of the phosphate group and the vibration of PO, respectively. Wide-scan XPS spectra of PCN-222-PA show the emergence of phosphorus signals around 133.9 eV, which can be ascribed to P 2p of PA molecules (f). In addition, the Zr 3d XPS spectra reveal a visible shift after PA modification (g), indicating that such molecules have been successfully anchored to the Zr6 clusters of PCN-222, instead of being adsorbed in MOF channels. To confirm the certain amount of the PA in PCN-222-PA, the PCN-222-PA sample was digested by KOH/D2O and characterized by the 1H NMR spectrum. As shown in Figure S2, “*” represents the peaks of TCPP, and the peaks around 3.5–4.5 ppm are attributed to the hydrogen in PA. A strong peak at 8.3 ppm for the hydrogen signal of HCOOH is present (Figure S2b) in PCN-222, and the peak area ratio (TCPP/HCOOH) is calculated as about 1:2, indicating that four formic acid molecules were capped in the Zr6 cluster of PCN-222. Such distinctive HCOOH peak almost disappears after PA modification (Figure S2a), indicating that PA molecules have been anchored to the Zr6 cluster of PCN-222 through a substitution way. Based on the 1H NMR spectrum of PCN-222-PA, the peak area ratio (TCPP/PA) is calculated as about 1:1, indicating that each Zr6 cluster in PCN-222 binds with about two PA molecules. To further confirm this, the contents of Zr and P were also measured by ICP after MOF digestion. The results show that the Zr/P molar ratio is calculated to be 1:1.96, which is consistent with the result of the 1H NMR spectrum. To investigate the thermal stability of PCN-222-PA, TGA was used. As shown in Figure S3, PCN-222-PA started to decompose from 100 °C due to the low boiling point of PA. About 32% of weight loss was observed as the temperature increases to 450 °C, which can be attributed to the degradation of both PA (mostly) and TCPP. Moreover, 31P NMR of PCN-222-PA was also characterized. As shown in Figure S4, the appearance of the phosphorus signal of PA indicates the successful modification of PCN-222. All these results demonstrate that each Zr6 cluster in PCN-222 binds with about two PA molecules. It should be noted that the BET surface area and N2 uptake capacity of PCN-222 have not decreased sharply after PA modification, which might be explained by the fact that two PA molecules bind with the Zr6 cluster by replacing four capped formic acid molecules instead of directly loading in the mesopore of PCN-222.

Herein, we have investigated different PA concentrations at 2.5, 5, and 50 mM. When the concentration of PA is 2.5 mM, as shown in Figure S2a, the peak area ratio (TCPP/PA) is calculated as 6:6.11. As the concentration reaches 5 mM, such peak area ratios have no obvious change (TCPP/PA = 6:6.37) (Figure S5), indicating that the PA loading has not changed obviously after the increase of PA concentration. This can be explained by the fact that the coordinated HCOOH in PCN-222 has almost been replaced by PA molecules at 2.5 mM, as evidenced by the nearly disappeared HCOOH peak at 8.3 ppm. To investigate the effect of PA concentration on linker/Zr loss and MOF degradation, the synthetic solution of PCN-222-PA after filtration was measured by ICP and UV spectroscopy (Figure S6). When the PA concentration was 2.5 mM, no Zr or TCPP was detected in the synthetic solution of PCN-222-PA. Similar results were observed as the concentration increases to 5 mM. However, when the concentration of PA reaches 50 mM, obvious Zr and TCPP were detected in the synthetic solution of PCN-222-PA, indicating that MOF structures start to be destroyed at this concentration, which can be ascribed to the strong affinity between the Zr6 cluster of PCN-222 and PO bonds in PA molecules. Therefore, the optimal PA concentration for the synthesis of PCN-222-PA was set as 2.5 mM.

Highly efficient extraction of radioactive uranium from aqueous solution remains a serious task in the nuclear energy field. To address this, we here create an effective uranium ion trap by using a novel and facile strategy that introduces bioinspired moiety phytic acid (PA) into highly robust PCN-222. The resultant metal–organic framework (MOF)-based uranium ion trap (PCN-222-PA) with a high density of accessible phosphate groups exhibits a remarkable U­(VI) uptake capacity (401.6 mg·g–1), surpassing most of the reported phosphorus-modified MOFs and various other MOF adsorbents. Kinetics study reveals that PCN-222-PA can reduce the uranium concentration from 10 mg L–1 to 21 μg L–1, below the acceptable limit defined by the US Environmental Protection Agency. In addition, PCN-222-PA also shows good selectivity and high stability as well as excellent recyclability toward uranium capture. Our work demonstrates a new strategy to design functional MOFs with abundant phosphate groups and provides a new perspective for extracting uranium from aqueous solution.

Herein, as a proof of concept, we demonstrate that such an effective uranium ion trap can be constructed by grafting bioinspired PA to a highly stable MOF (PCN-222) through a postsynthetic method (PSM), which is always regarded as a common method in MOF modification. To the best of our knowledge, our work presents the first study to use PA-functionalized MOF for uranium capture. As a result, the resultant MOF-based uranium ion trap (PCN-222-PA) bearing high-density accessible phosphate groups exhibits a remarkable U­(VI) uptake capacity (401.6 mg·g–1), surpassing most of the phosphorus-modified MOFs and various other MOF-based adsorbents. Kinetics study reveals that PCN-222-PA can reduce the U­(VI) concentration from 10 mg L–1 to 21 μg L–1, below the acceptable limit defined by the US Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA). Furthermore, PCN-222-PA also possesses good selectivity and high stability as well as excellent recyclability toward U­(VI) capture, suggesting its great potential in practical application.

a shows the PXRD patterns of PCN-222-PA and original PCN-222. It is visible that the related peaks of these two MOFs are closely matched, indicating that the crystal structure of PCN-222 remains intact after PA module insertion. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of PCN-222 and PCN-222-PA measured at 77 K display a typical type IV isotherm and exhibit a steep increase at the point of P/P 0 = 0.3 (b), suggesting the reservation of a mesoporous feature after introducing PA molecules into PCN-222, despite a decrease of their Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas from 2330 m2·g–1 for PCN-222 to 2197 m2·g–1 for PCN-222-PA. The mesopore size has decreased from 32 to 26 Å for PCN-222-PA (Figure S1), suggesting the successful introduction of PA into the MOF structure. The SEM images show that PCN-222-PA particles possess a rod-shaped morphology, with no obvious morphology change being observed after PA insertion (c,d). The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of PCN-222-PA demonstrates the emergence of phosphorus elements after modification, suggesting the successful grafting of PA molecules in PCN-222. Besides, phosphorus disperses uniformly in PCN-222-PA, indicating well-dispersion of PA molecules within the crystal structure of our uranium ion trap.

The successful grafting of PA molecules onto PCN-222 was also examined by FTIR, XPS, and ICP analyses. As shown in e, the FTIR spectra of PCN-222-PA reveal two new peaks at 574 and 1106 cm–1 compared with those of the original one, which can be attributed to the in-side-plane vibration of the phosphate group and the vibration of PO, respectively. Wide-scan XPS spectra of PCN-222-PA show the emergence of phosphorus signals around 133.9 eV, which can be ascribed to P 2p of PA molecules (f). In addition, the Zr 3d XPS spectra reveal a visible shift after PA modification (g), indicating that such molecules have been successfully anchored to the Zr6 clusters of PCN-222, instead of being adsorbed in MOF channels. To confirm the certain amount of the PA in PCN-222-PA, the PCN-222-PA sample was digested by KOH/D2O and characterized by the 1H NMR spectrum. As shown in Figure S2, “*” represents the peaks of TCPP, and the peaks around 3.5–4.5 ppm are attributed to the hydrogen in PA. A strong peak at 8.3 ppm for the hydrogen signal of HCOOH is present (Figure S2b) in PCN-222, and the peak area ratio (TCPP/HCOOH) is calculated as about 1:2, indicating that four formic acid molecules were capped in the Zr6 cluster of PCN-222. Such distinctive HCOOH peak almost disappears after PA modification (Figure S2a), indicating that PA molecules have been anchored to the Zr6 cluster of PCN-222 through a substitution way. Based on the 1H NMR spectrum of PCN-222-PA, the peak area ratio (TCPP/PA) is calculated as about 1:1, indicating that each Zr6 cluster in PCN-222 binds with about two PA molecules. The results show that the Zr/P molar ratio is calculated to be 1:1.96, which is consistent with the result of the 1H NMR spectrum. To investigate the thermal stability of PCN-222-PA, TGA was used. As shown in Figure S3, PCN-222-PA started to decompose from 100 °C due to the low boiling point of PA. About 32% of weight loss was observed as the temperature increases to 450 °C, which can be attributed to the degradation of both PA (mostly) and TCPP. Moreover, 31P NMR of PCN-222-PA was also characterized. As shown in Figure S4, the appearance of the phosphorus signal of PA indicates the successful modification of PCN-222. All these results demonstrate that each Zr6 cluster in PCN-222 binds with about two PA molecules. It should be noted that the BET surface area and N2 uptake capacity of PCN-222 have not decreased sharply after PA modification, which might be explained by the fact that two PA molecules bind with the Zr6 cluster by replacing four capped formic acid molecules instead of directly loading in the mesopore of PCN-222.
